selected_quotes: Turn-taking in Human Communication – Origins and Implications for Language Processing: Trends in Cognitive Sciences
The Levinson article on gaps (behind a pay wall) is here, if your uni library subscribes

citation.abstract: Most language usage is interactive, involving rapid turn-taking. The turn-taking system has a number of striking properties: turns are short and responses are remarkably rapid, but turns are of varying length and often of very complex construction such that the underlying cognitive processing is highly compressed. Although neglected in cognitive science, the system has deep implications for language processing and acquisition that are only now becoming clear. Appearing earlier in ontogeny than linguistic competence, it is also found across all the major primate clades. This suggests a possible phylogenetic continuity, which may provide key insights into language evolution.
citation.title: Turn-taking in Human Communication – Origins and Implications for Language Processing

news.title: Babies learn turn-taking much before they can speak
news.summary: London: Taking turns to respond to each other is a key part of conversation, and babies learn the technique at around six months of age, long before infants know much about language, says a new study.

news.title: The Incredible Thing We Do During Conversations
news.summary: One of the greatest human skills becomes evident during conversations. It’s there, not in what we say but in what we don’t.

news.title: When to stay quiet and when to speak up
news.summary: At your next meeting, wait for a pause in conversation and try to measure how long it lasts.

news.title: The power of silence: He who speaks first loses the deal
news.summary: In business and in life, it could help you to get acquainted with the power of the pause.
